translated: The one with copper-colored earth-rings, with mountains, full of lion faces, with a family,

translated: The golden-hued earth, shining like gold, covered with golden dust, as if arranged,

analyzed: śyāma sthala āḍhyam bahu śasya bhūti dam lasat tṛṇaiḥ babbula vṛkṣa vṛddhi dam
translated: Rich in dark-colored fields, bestowing abundance of crops, shining with grass, promoting the growth of babul trees,

original: dhānyodbhavaiḥ karṣakalokaharṣadaṃ jagāda śaudraṃ jagatau vṛṣadhvajaḥ // /
analyzed: dhānya udbhavaiḥ karṣaka loka harṣa dam jagāda śaudram jagatau vṛṣadhvajaḥ
translated: Producing grains, delighting the farming people, the Bull-Bannered One declared this to be the Shudra caste in the world.

original: dravyaṃ kṣetrād uditam anaghaṃ brāhma tat siddhidāyi kṣatrād utthaṃ valipalitajid viśvarogāpahāri /
analyzed: dravyam kṣetrāt uditam anagham brāhma tat siddhi dāyi kṣatrāt uttham vali palita jit viśva roga apahāri
translated: The substance that arises from a Brahmin field is pure and bestows success; that which arises from a Kshatriya destroys old age and all diseases;

original: vaiśyāj jātaṃ prabhavatitarāṃ dhātulohādisiddhau śaudrād etaj janitam akhilavyādhividrāvakaṃ drāk // /
analyzed: vaiśyāt jātam prabhavatitarām dhātu loha ādi siddhau śaudrāt etat janitam akhila vyādhi vidrāvakam drāk
translated: That which arises from a Vaishya is extremely effective in the preparation of metals, iron, and so on; that which arises from a Shudra quickly drives away all diseases.

original: brahmā śakraḥ kiṃnareśas tathā bhūr ity eteṣāṃ devatāḥ syuḥ krameṇa /
analyzed: brahmā śakraḥ kiṃnareśaḥ tathā bhūḥ iti eteṣām devatāḥ syuḥ krameṇa
translated: Brahma, Shakra, the king of the Kinnaras, and the Earth - these are their respective deities.

original: proktās tatra prāg umāvallabhena pratyekaṃ te pañca bhūtāni vakṣye // /
analyzed: proktāḥ tatra prāk umāvallabhena pratyekam te pañca bhūtāni vakṣye
translated: The Lord of Uma has previously declared them. I will now describe each of the five elements.

analyzed: pīta sphurat valaya śarkarila aśma ramyam pītam yat uttama mṛgam caturasra bhūtam
translated: The yellow one, beautiful with yellow sand and pebbles, which is square, and is the best of the animals.

original: prāyaś ca pītakusumānvitavīrudādi tat pārthivaṃ kaṭhinam udyad aśeṣatas tu // /🔽ardhacandrākṛtiśvetaṃ kamalābhaṃ dṛṣaccitam /
analyzed: prāyas ca pīta kusuma anvita vīrudh ādi tat pārthivam kaṭhinam udyat aśeṣatas tu  ardhacandra ākṛti śvetam kamala ābham dṛṣad citam
translated: And mostly the earthly one is hard, with trees etc. having yellow flowers, but the rising one is entirely of all kinds.🔽The watery field is said to be half-moon-shaped, white, lotus-like, and full of stones.

original: nadīnadajalākīrṇam āpyaṃ tat kṣetram ucyate // /🔽khadirādidrumākīrṇaṃ bhūricitrakaveṇukam /
analyzed: nadīnada jala ākīrṇam āpyam tat kṣetram ucyate  khadira ādi druma ākīrṇam bhūri citraka veṇukam
translated: It is full of the water of rivers and streams.

analyzed: tri koṇam rakta pāṣāṇam kṣetram taijasam uttamam
translated: The excellent fiery field is triangular, full of trees like khadira etc., with plenty of variegated bamboo, and has red stones.

analyzed: dhūmra sthalam dhūmra dṛṣad parītam ṣaṣ koṇakam tūrṇa mṛga avakīrṇam
translated: The smoky field is surrounded by smoky stones, is hexagonal, and is scattered with swift deer.

original: śākais tṛṇair añcitarūkṣavṛkṣakaṃ prakāram etat khalu vāyavīyam // /
analyzed: śākaiḥ tṛṇaiḥ añcita rūkṣa vṛkṣakam prakāram etat khalu vāyavīyam
translated: This type is indeed the airy one, with rough trees covered with vegetables and grass.

original: nānāvarṇaṃ vartulaṃ tat praśastaṃ prāyaḥ śubhraṃ parvatākīrṇam uccaiḥ /
analyzed: nānā varṇam vartulam tat praśastam prāyas śubhram parvata ākīrṇam uccais
translated: That is praised as being of various colors, mostly white, and is high, scattered with mountains.

original: yac ca sthānaṃ pāvanaṃ devatānāṃ prāha kṣetraṃ trīkṣaṇas tv āntarikṣam // /
analyzed: yat ca sthānam pāvanam devatānām prāha kṣetram trīkṣaṇaḥ tu āntarikṣam
translated: And the three-eyed one says that the place which is sacred to the gods is the atmospheric field.

original: dravyaṃ vyādhiharaṃ balātiśayakṛt svādu sthiraṃ pārthivaṃ syād āpyaṃ kaṭukaṃ kaṣāyam akhilaṃ śītaṃ ca pittāpaham /
analyzed: dravyam vyādhi haram bala atiśaya kṛt svādu sthiram pārthivam syāt āpyam kaṭukam kaṣāyam akhilam śītam ca pitta apaham
translated: The substance that removes diseases, increases strength, is sweet and stable, is earthly; the watery one is bitter, astringent, all, cold, and removes bile.

original: yat tiktaṃ lavaṇaṃ ca dīpyamarujic coṣṇaṃ ca tat taijasaṃ vāyavyaṃ tu himoṣṇam amlam abalaṃ syān nābhasaṃ nīrasam // /
analyzed: yat tiktam lavaṇam ca dīpya maru jit ca uṣṇam ca tat taijasam vāyavyam tu hima uṣṇam amlam abalam syāt nābhasam nīrasam
translated: That which is bitter, salty, pungent, hot, and sharp is of the fire element. That which is cold and hot is of the wind element. That which is sour and weak is of the water element. That which is tasteless is of the earth element.

original: brahmā viṣṇuś ca rudro 'smād īśvaro 'tha sadāśivaḥ /
analyzed: brahmā viṣṇuḥ ca smāt sadāśivaḥ
translated: Brahmā, Viṣṇu, Rudra, Īśvara, and Sadāśiva -

analyzed: iti etāḥ kamataḥ pañca kṣetra bhūta adhidevatāḥ
translated: these are the five presiding deities of the field, in this order.

original: jitvā javād ajarasainyam ihājahāra vīraḥ purā yudhi sudhākalaśaṃ garutmān /
analyzed: jitvā javāt ajara sainyam iha ājahāra vīraḥ purā yudhi sudhā kalaśam garutmān
translated: In ancient times, the hero Garuḍa quickly conquered the invincible army here and took away the nectar pot in battle.

original: kīrṇais tadā bhuvi sudhāśakalaiḥ kilāsīd vṛkṣādikaṃ sakalam asya sudhāṃśur īśaḥ // /🔽tatrotpannās tūttame kṣetrabhāge viprīyādau vipruṣo yatra yatra /
analyzed: kīrṇaiḥ tadā bhuvi sudhā śakalaiḥ kila āsīt vṛkṣa ādikam sakalam asya sudhāṃśuḥ īśaḥ  / tatra utpannāḥ tu uttame kṣetra bhāge vipruṣaḥ yatra yatra
translated: Then, the nectar drops scattered on the ground by him became the moon, and everything like trees and so on became nectar.🔽The drops that fell on the excellent part of the field, there they became the Brahmins, Kṣatriyas, Vaiśyas, and Śūdras.

original: kṣauṇījādidravyabhūyaṃ prapannās tās tāḥ saṃjñā bibhrate tatra bhūyaḥ // /
analyzed: kṣauṇīja ādi dravya bhūyam prapannāḥ tāḥ tāḥ saṃjñāḥ bibhrate tatra bhūyas
translated: Having attained the state of earth-born substances, they again bear those names there.

analyzed: evam kṣetra ānuguṇyena tad jāḥ vipra ādi varṇinaḥ
translated: Thus, the Brahmins and others born from the field, according to the characteristics of the field,

original: yadi vā lakṣaṇaṃ vakṣyāmy amohāya manīṣiṇām // /
analyzed: yadi vā lakṣaṇam vakṣyāmi amohāya manīṣiṇām
translated: or if I describe the characteristics for the benefit of the wise.

original: kisalayakusume prakāṇḍaśākhādiṣu viśadeṣu vadanti vipram etān /
analyzed: kisalaya kusume prakāṇḍa śākhā ādiṣu viśadeṣu vadanti vipram etān
translated: When the tender leaves, flowers, trunk, branches, and so on are clear, they call them Brahmins.

analyzed: narapatim ati lohiteṣu vaiśyam kanaka nibheṣu sitetareṣu śūdram
translated: If the king is very red, the Vaishya is golden in color, and the Shudra is white.

analyzed: vipra ādi jāti sambhūtān vipra ādiṣu eva yojayet
translated: One should employ those born in the Brahmin and other castes only among Brahmins and other castes.

original: guṇāḍhyān api vṛkṣādīn prātilomyaṃ na cācaret // /
analyzed: guṇa āḍhyān api vṛkṣa ādīn prātilomyam na ca ācaret
translated: Even if endowed with qualities, one should not act contrary to the order of trees and so on.

original: vipro viprādyeṣu varṇeṣu rājā rājanyādau vaiśyamukhyeṣu vaiśyaḥ /
analyzed: vipraḥ vipra ādyeṣu varṇeṣu rājā rājani ādau vaiśya mukhyeṣu vaiśyaḥ
translated: A Brahmin among Brahmins and other castes, a king among Kshatriyas and others, a Vaishya among Vaishyas and others,

original: śūdraḥ śūdrādyeṣu śastaṃ guṇāḍhyaṃ dravyaṃ naiva prātilomyena kiṃcit // /
analyzed: śūdraḥ śūdra ādyeṣu śastam guṇa āḍhyam dravyam na eva prātilomyena kiṃcid
translated: A Shudra among Shudras and others - one should not use any substance contrary to the order, even if it is praised and endowed with qualities.

original: dravyaṃ yad aṅkūrajam āhur āryās tat te punaḥ pañcavidhaṃ vadanti /
analyzed: dravyam yat aṅkūra jam āhuḥ āryāḥ tat te punar pañcavidham vadanti
translated: The noble ones say that the substance born from a seed is of five types.

original: vanaspatiś cāpi sa eva vānaspatyaḥ kṣupo vīrud athauṣadhīś ca // /
analyzed: vanaspatiḥ ca api saḥ eva vānaspatyaḥ kṣupaḥ vīrudh atha auṣadhīḥ ca
translated: That is indeed a tree, a non-tree, a small tree, a creeper, and a herb.

original: jñeyaḥ so 'tra vanaspatiḥ phalati yaḥ puṣpair vinā taiḥ phalaṃ vānaspatya iti smṛtas tanur asau hrasvaḥ kṣupaḥ kathyate /
analyzed: jñeyaḥ saḥ tra vanaspatiḥ phalati yaḥ puṣpaiḥ vinā taiḥ phalam vānaspatyaḥ iti smṛtaḥ tanuḥ asau hrasvaḥ kṣupaḥ kathyate
translated: That which bears fruit here without flowers is known as a tree. That slender one is called a small tree.

original: yā vellatyagamādisaṃśrayavaśād eṣā tu vallī matā śālyādiḥ punar oṣadhiḥ phalaparīpākāvasānānvitā // /
analyzed: yā vellati agama ādi saṃśraya vaśāt eṣā tu vallī matā śāli ādiḥ punar oṣadhiḥ phala parīpāka avasāna anvitā
translated: This is considered a creeper due to its dependence on other things for support. Rice and other grains are herbs, ending with the ripening of the fruit.

analyzed: strī pum napuṃsaka tvena traividhyam sthāvareṣu api
translated: Even among immobile things, there are three types: female, male, and neuter.

original: śṛṇu vakṣyāmi tallakṣma vyaktam atra yathākramam // /
analyzed: śṛṇu vakṣyāmi tat lakṣma vyaktam atra yathākramam
translated: Listen, I will describe their characteristics clearly here in order.

analyzed: ikṣu veṇu taru vīrudh ādayaḥ skandha kāṇḍa phala puṣpa pallavaiḥ
translated: Sugarcane, bamboo, trees, creepers, etc., with trunks, stems, fruits, flowers, and sprouts,

original: snigdhadīrghatanutāmanoramās tāḥ striyaḥ khalu matā vipaścitām // /
analyzed: snigdha dīrgha tanu tā manoramāḥ tāḥ striyaḥ khalu matāḥ vipaścitām
translated: Are considered by the wise to be women, being smooth, long, slender, and charming.

analyzed: yatra puṣpa pravāla ādi na ati dīrgham na ca alpakam
translated: Where the flowers, sprouts, etc. are not too long or too short,

original: sthūlaṃ paruṣam ity eṣa pumān ukto manīṣibhiḥ // /
analyzed: sthūlam paruṣam iti eṣa pumān uktaḥ manīṣibhiḥ
translated: And are thick and rough, this is said by the wise to be a man.

original: strīpuṃsayor yatra vibhāti lakṣma dvayor api skandhaphalādikeṣu /
analyzed: strīpuṃsayoḥ yatra vibhāti lakṣma dvayoḥ api skandha phala ādikeṣu
translated: Where the characteristics of both a woman and a man appear in the trunks, fruits, etc. of both,

analyzed: saṃdeha dam na ekatara avadhāri napuṃsakam tat vibudhāḥ vadanti
translated: The wise say that is a hermaphrodite, causing doubt and not determining one or the other.

original: dravyaṃ pumān syād akhilasya jantor ārogyadaṃ tadbalavardhanaṃ ca /
analyzed: dravyam pumān syāt akhilasya jantoḥ ārogya dam tad bala vardhanam ca
translated: A substance should be a man, giving health and increasing strength to all beings.

original: strī durbalā svalpaguṇā guṇāḍhyā strīṣv eva na kvāpi napuṃsakaḥ syāt // /
analyzed: strī durbalā su alpa guṇā guṇa āḍhyā strīṣu eva na kva api napuṃsakaḥ syāt
translated: A woman is weak and has few qualities, but a woman endowed with qualities is never a hermaphrodite.

original: yadi striyaḥ strīṣu kṛtā guṇāḍhyāḥ klībāni tu klībaśarīrabhājām /
analyzed: yadi striyaḥ strīṣu kṛtāḥ guṇa āḍhyāḥ klībāni tu klība śarīra bhājām
translated: If women are endowed with qualities among women, but eunuchs have bodies of eunuchs,

original: sadā ca sarvatra pumān prayuktau guṇāvahaś ceti ca kecid āhuḥ // /
analyzed: sadā ca sarvatra pumān prayuktau guṇa āvahaḥ ca iti ca kecid āhuḥ
translated: And if a man is always used everywhere, some say that is conducive to virtue.

original: kṣutpipāsā ca nidrā ca vṛkṣādiṣv api lakṣyate /
analyzed: kṣudh pipāsā ca nidrā ca vṛkṣa ādiṣu api lakṣyate
translated: Hunger, thirst, and sleep are observed even in trees and other things.

analyzed: mṛd jala ādānataḥ tu ādye parṇa saṃkocita antimā
translated: But in the first, due to the contact of earth and water, the last is contracted in leaves.

original: yatkāṭhinye sā kṣitiryodbhavo 'mbhastejastūṣmā vardhate yat sa vātaḥ /
analyzed: yat kāṭhinye sā kṣitiḥ yā udbhavaḥ mbhaḥ tejaḥ tu ūṣmā vardhate yat sa vātaḥ
translated: That which is hardness is earth, that which is rising is water, that which increases heat is fire, and that which is wind is air.

original: yad yac chidraṃ tan nabhaḥ sthāvarāṇām ity eteṣāṃ pañcabhūtātmakatvam // /
analyzed: yat yat chidram tat nabhaḥ sthāvarāṇām iti eteṣām pañcabhūta ātmaka tvam
translated: That which is a hole is space. Thus, these [five elements] have the nature of the five elements.

analyzed: ittham deśa guṇa svarūpa kathana prakrānta kāntāra ja kṣetra dravya guṇa anvaya kramam imam vargam paṭhitvā naraḥ
translated: Having recited this group of verses in the sequence of the qualities of the country, the forest, the field, and the substances, which were begun in the description of the nature of the qualities, a man

analyzed: prāpnoti āśu bhiṣak prayoga viṣaya prāvīṇya pārīṇa tā ahaṃkurvāṇa suparva saṃsad agadaṅkāra kriyā kauśalam
translated: quickly attains the skill in the practice of a physician, boasting of his mastery, in the skillful performance of medical treatment in the assembly of the well-parted [hair].

analyzed: asūta sutam īśvaraḥ śruta yaśāḥ yam aṣṭādaśa prabheda vidha vāc maya ambunidhi pāra pārīṇa dhīḥ
translated: The Lord, whose fame is heard, whose mind has crossed to the other shore of the ocean of the eighteen varieties of language, has given birth to a son.

original: amuṣya nṛharīśituḥ kṛtivarasya vargaḥ kṛtāvasāvagamadādimaḥ sadabhidhānacūḍāmaṇau // /
analyzed: amuṣya nṛhari īśituḥ kṛti varasya vargaḥ kṛtau asau agamat ādimaḥ sat abhidhāna cūḍāmaṇau
translated: This first group of the excellent works of that Lord of men, Hari, has been composed in the crest-jewel of composition, the Ādimad.

analyzed: rājanighaṇṭu
translated: The Royal Dictionary.

analyzed: dharaṇī ādi varga
translated: The Group of Earth and Other [Elements]

analyzed: atha dharaṇi dharitrī bhūtadhātrī dharā bhū kṣiti mahidharaṇī iḍā kṣmā avanī medinī ijyā
translated: Then, the earth, the sustainer of the mountains, the mother, the supporter, the great earth, the abode of the mountains, the earth, the earth, the worthy of worship,

original: avanirudadhivastrā gauḥ kṣamā kṣauṇir urvī kurapi vasumatīrā kāśyapī ratragarbhā // /🔽kṣamādimā bhūmirilā vasundharā varā ca dhātrī vasudhācalorvarā /
analyzed: avaniḥ udadhi vastrā gauḥ kṣamā kṣā oṇiḥ urvī kuḥ api vasumatī irā kāśyapī ratra garbhā  / kṣama ādimā bhūmiḥ ilā vasundharā varā ca dhātrī vasudhā acalā urvarā
translated: The earth, the ocean-clad, the cow, the forgiving, the land, the field, the Kurpa, the wealthy, the daughter of Kashyapa, the womb of night...🔽The earth, the forgiving, the earth, the Iila, the Vasundhara, the excellent, the mother, the wealth-bearing, the mountain-like,

original: viśvambharādyā jagatī kṣitī rasā pṛthvī ca gotrā pṛthivī pṛthur mahī // /
analyzed: viśvambharā ādyā jagatī kṣitiḥ rasā pṛthvī ca gotrā pṛthivī pṛthuḥ mahī
translated: The supporter of the universe, and so on, the earth, the land, the essence, the Prithvi, the lineage, the earth, the vast, the great...

analyzed: kṣauṇī sarvasahā anantā bhūtamātā ca niścalā
translated: The earth, the all-enduring, the mother of beings, the unmoving,

original: bhūmī vījaprasūḥ śyāmā kroḍakāntā ca kīrtitā // /🔽sā bhūmir urvarākhyā yā sarvaśasyodbhavapradā /
analyzed: sā bhūmiḥ urvarā ākhyā yā sarva śasya udbhava pradā
translated: The earth, the seed-giver, the dark, the one with the womb, is said to be...🔽That earth is called the fertile one, which gives rise to all crops.

analyzed: samasta vastu udbhavanāt urvarā nāma bhūḥ iyam
translated: This earth is called the fertile one because it gives rise to all things...

original: mṛn mṛttikā praśastā sā mṛtsā mṛtsneti ceṣyate // /
analyzed: mṛd mṛttikā praśastā sā mṛtsā mṛtsnā iti ca iṣyate
translated: The clay, the clay, the praised, that clay is desired to be called the clay...

original: kṣārā mṛdūṣaro deśas tadvān iraṇam ūṣaram /🔽khilam aprahataṃ prāhur dhanvā tu marur ucyate // /
analyzed: kṣārāḥ mṛdu ūṣaraḥ deśaḥ tadvān ūṣaram  khilam aprahatam prāhuḥ dhanvā tu maruḥ ucyate
translated: The salty, the clay, the barren land, the possessor of that, the barren land, the Irana, the salt...🔽The unploughed land is said to be the Khil, but the desert is said to be the Dhanva...

original: maruprāyas tu yo deśaḥ sa cokto jāṅgalābhidhaḥ /
analyzed: maru prāyaḥ tu yaḥ deśaḥ sa ca uktaḥ jāṅgala abhidhaḥ
translated: The land which is mostly desert is also said to be called Jangala...

original: kṛṣṇamṛt kṛṣṇabhūmiḥ syāt pāṇḍubhūmis tu pāṇḍumṛt // /🔽sa śārkaraḥ śārkarilo deśo yaḥ śarkarānvitaḥ /
analyzed: kṛṣṇamṛd kṛṣṇa bhūmiḥ syāt pāṇḍu bhūmiḥ tu pāṇḍumṛd  sa śārkaraḥ deśaḥ yaḥ śarkarā anvitaḥ
translated: Krishna-mrit means black soil, while Pandu-mrit means white soil.🔽A country that is full of gravel is called Shar-kara-la, Shar-karila, or Shar-kariva.

original: saikataḥ syāt sikatilaḥ sikatāvāṃś ca yo bhavet // /
analyzed: saikataḥ syāt sikatilaḥ sikatāvān ca yaḥ bhavet
translated: A country that is full of sand is called Saikata, Sika-tila, or Sika-van.

analyzed: deśaḥ janapadaḥ nīvṛt viṣayaḥ ca upavarttanam
translated: A country is also called a Janapada, a Nivri, a Vishaya, or an Upavartana.

original: pradeśaḥ sthānam ākhyā bhūr avakāśaḥ sthitiḥ padam // /
analyzed: pradeśaḥ sthānam ākhyā bhūḥ avakāśaḥ sthitiḥ padam
translated: A place is also called a Pradesha, a Sthana, an Akhya, a Bhu, an Avakasha, a Sthiti, or a Pada.

analyzed: nadī ambu jaiḥ bhṛtaḥ dhānyaiḥ nadī mātrakaḥ ucyate
translated: A country that is irrigated by the water of rivers and is full of rice is called Nadi-matraka.

original: vṛṣṭyambajais tu tair eṣa deśaḥ syād devamātṛkaḥ // /🔽nadīvṛṣṭijalodbhūtair nānādhānyaiḥ samāvṛtaḥ /
analyzed: vṛṣṭyamba jaiḥ tu taiḥ eṣa deśaḥ syāt devamātṛkaḥ  nadī vṛṣṭi jala udbhūtaiḥ nānā dhānyaiḥ samāvṛtaḥ
translated: But a country that is irrigated by the rain water and is full of rice is called Deva-matrika.

analyzed: deśaḥ dvaya anugamanāt sa dvaimātṛkaḥ ucyate
translated: A country that is surrounded by various kinds of rice grown from the water of rivers and rain is called Dvai-matrika because it follows two ways.

original: mudgādīnāṃ kṣetram udbhūtidaṃ yat tan maudgīnaṃ kodravīṇaṃ tathānyat /
analyzed: mudga ādīnām kṣetram udbhūti dam yat tat maudgīnam kodravīṇam tathā anyat
translated: A field where mudga etc. are produced is called Maudgiana, Kodravana, and similarly Vraihayana.

original: vraiheyaṃ syāt kiṃca śāleyam evaṃ buddhāṇavyañcāṇavīnaṃ ca vidyāt // /
analyzed: vraiheyam syāt kiṃca śāleyam evam ca vidyāt
translated: One should know that Shaileyana is also like that, and Buddhanavya and Anchavana.

original: atha māṣyaṃ māṣīṇaṃ bhaṅgyaṃ bhāṅgīnam umyam aumīnam /
analyzed: atha māṣyam māṣīṇam umyam aumīnam
translated: Now, Masya, Masina, Bhangya, Bhangina, Umya, Omina,

original: tilyaṃ tailīnaṃ syād iti ṣaṣṭikyaṃ ca yavyaṃ ca // /
analyzed: tilyam tailīnam syāt iti ṣaṣṭikyam ca yavyam ca
translated: Tilya, Tailina, and similarly Shashtikya and Yava.

original: śākāder yatra niṣpattir etat syāc chākaśākaṭam /
analyzed: śāka ādeḥ yatra niṣpattiḥ etat syāt śākaśākaṭam
translated: Where there is the production of vegetables etc., that would be Śākaśākaṭa.

analyzed: śākaśākinam iti etat tathā  atha giri dharaṇīdhra gotra bhūbhṛt śikhari śiloccaya śaila sānumantaḥ
translated: This is Śākaśākin, and likewise Vāstūkaśākaṭa.🔽Now, the mountains are the abode of the mountain-born, the peaks of the mountain-born, the rocky hills, the mountain ranges, and the mountain tops.

original: kṣitibhṛdaganagāvanīdharādristhirakudharāś ca dharādharo dharaś ca // /🔽ahāryaḥ parvato grāvā kaṭakī prasthavān api /
analyzed: kṣitibhṛt aga naga avanīdhara adri sthira kudharāḥ ca dharādharaḥ dharaḥ ca  ahāryaḥ parvataḥ grāvā kaṭakī prasthavān api
translated: The mountains are the abode of the mountain-born, the peaks of the mountain-born, the rocky hills, the mountain ranges, and the mountain tops.🔽The mountain is unremovable, the stone is Grāvā, the rock is Kaṭakī, and the hill is Prasthavat.

original: śṛṅgī ca vṛkṣavāṃś ceti śabdāḥ śailārthavācakāḥ // /
analyzed: śṛṅgī ca vṛkṣavān ca iti śabdāḥ śaila artha vācakāḥ
translated: The words Śṛṅgī and Vṛkṣavān are denotative of mountain.

original: madhyamas tu nitambaḥ syāt kaṭakaṃ mekhalā ca sā /
analyzed: madhyamaḥ tu nitambaḥ syāt kaṭakam mekhalā ca sā
translated: But the middle is Nitaṃba, and that is Kaṭaka and Mekhalā.

original: taṭe taṭī prapātaś ca prasthe snuḥ sānusānunī // /
analyzed: taṭe taṭī prapātaḥ ca prasthe snuḥ sānu sānunī  /
translated: The bank is Taṭa, the precipice is Taṭī and Prapāta, and the plateau is Snu, Sānu and Sānu.

original: śṛṅgaṃ tu śikharaṃ kūṭaṃ kandare kandarā darī /
analyzed: śṛṅgam tu śikharam kūṭam kandare kandarā darī
translated: The peak is Śikhara, Kūṭa, in the cave is Kandarā and Darī.

original: vilaṃ guhā śilāsandhir devakhātaṃ ca gahvaram // /
analyzed: vilam guhā śilā sandhiḥ devakhātam ca gahvaram
translated: The cave is Guhā, the rocky junction is Śilāsandhi, and the chasm is Devakhāta and Gahvara.

analyzed: pratyanta girayaḥ pādāḥ gaṇḍaśailāḥ cyuta upalāḥ
translated: The border mountains are Pāda, the subsidiary mountains are Gaṇḍaśaila and Cyutaupala.

original: ākaraḥ khanir ity ukto dhātavo gairikādayaḥ // /
analyzed: ākaraḥ khaniḥ iti uktaḥ dhātavaḥ gairika ādayaḥ
translated: The mine is said to be Khāṇi, and the minerals are Gairika and others.

analyzed: grāvā prastara pāṣāṇau dṛṣad aśma upalaḥ śilā
translated: The stone is Grāvā, the rock is Prasthara and Pāṣāṇa, the stone is Dṛṣad, Aśma and Upala, and the rock is Śilā.

analyzed: lohāni vividhāni syuḥ aśmasāra ādi saṃjñayā
translated: Various kinds of metals are denoted by the terms aśmasāra and so on.

original: kānanaṃ gahanaṃ satraṃ kāntāraṃ vipinaṃ vanam /
analyzed: kānanam gahanam satram kāntāram vipinam vanam
translated: Kānana, gahana, satra, kāntāra, vipina, and vana are synonyms for forest.

original: araṇyam aṭavī dāvo davaś ca vanavācakāḥ // /
analyzed: araṇyam aṭavī dāvaḥ davaḥ ca vana vācakāḥ
translated: Arani, aṭavī, dāva, and dava are also words denoting forest.

original: anyad udyānam ākrīḍo yatra krīḍanti rāgiṇaḥ /
analyzed: anyat udyānam ākrīḍaḥ yatra krīḍanti rāgiṇaḥ
translated: Any garden is an ākaraṇa, where passionate people play.

analyzed: nṛpa ālayeṣu pramada vanam antaḥpura ucitam
translated: In royal palaces, the pleasure garden is suitable for the inner apartments.

analyzed: mahā vanam araṇyānī mahā araṇyam mahā aṭavī
translated: Mahāvana, araṇyāṇī, mahāraṇya, and mahāṭavī are also used for forest.

original: athopavanam ārāmaḥ puraprānte vanaṃ tu yat // /
analyzed: atha upavanam ārāmaḥ pura prānte vanam tu yat
translated: Then, an upavana is an ārama, which is a forest near the outskirts of a city.

original: kujaḥ kṣitiruho 'ṅghripaḥ śikharipādapau viṣṭaraḥ kuṭhas tarur anokahaḥ kuruhabhūruhadrudrumāḥ /
analyzed: kujaḥ kṣitiruhaḥ ṅghripaḥ śikhari pādapau viṣṭaraḥ kuṭhaḥ taruḥ anokahaḥ kuruha bhūruha dru drumāḥ
translated: Mars, earth, tree, foot, mountain, tree, seat, stick, tree, forest, Kuru, Bhūruha, Druma are the names of trees.

analyzed: agaḥ naga vanaspatī viṭapi śākhi bhūja agamāḥ mahīja dharaṇīruha kṣitija vṛkṣa śāla ādayaḥ
translated: Non-cow, mountain, tree, branch, tree, hand, born from the earth, earth, horizon, tree, hall, etc. are used for trees.

original: phalitaḥ phalavān eṣa phalinaś ca phalī tathā /
analyzed: phalitaḥ phalavān eṣa phalinaḥ ca phalī tathā
translated: The fruited one, the fruitful one, this one, and the fruit-bearing ones are also so.

original: phalegrahir abandhyo yaḥ syād amoghaphalodayaḥ // /🔽athāvakeśī bandhyo 'yaṃ viphalo niṣphalo 'phalaḥ /
analyzed: phalegrahiḥ abandhyaḥ yaḥ syāt amogha phala udayaḥ  atha avakeśī bandhyaḥ yam viphalaḥ niṣphalaḥ phalaḥ
translated: The one who grasps the fruit, the unbarren one, the one with unfailing fruit, is the one with the rise of unfailing fruit.

analyzed: uktau prāk ātmanā bhinnau vānaspatya vanaspatī
translated: Now, this barren one, the fruitless one, the fruitless one, the fruitless one, the fruitless one, is spoken of as different from the tree by the self.

original: mūlaṃ tu netraṃ pādaḥ syād aṅghriścaraṇam ity api /
analyzed: mūlam tu netram pādaḥ syāt aṅghriḥ caraṇam iti api
translated: The root is the eye, the foot is the leg, and the foot is also the foot.🔽The sprout should be known as the shoot, and the shoot is also the sprout.

original: udbhedas tv aṅkuro jñeyaḥ praroho 'ṅkūra ity api // /🔽arvāgbhāgo 'sya budhnaḥ syāt nitambaḥ sapṛthur bhavet /
analyzed: udbhedaḥ tu aṅkuraḥ jñeyaḥ prarohaḥ ṅkūraḥ iti api  arvāc bhāgaḥ sya budhnaḥ syāt nitambaḥ sa pṛthuḥ bhavet
translated: The lower part of this is the base, and the buttocks should be large.

original: āskandhāt ta prakāṇḍaḥ syāt kāṇḍo daṇḍaś ca kathyate // /🔽skandhapramāṇāsya latās tu śākhāḥ skandhotthaśākhās tu bhavanti śālāḥ /
analyzed: ā skandhāt prakāṇḍaḥ syāt kāṇḍaḥ daṇḍaḥ ca kathyate  latāḥ tu śākhāḥ skandha uttha śākhāḥ tu bhavanti śālāḥ
translated: From the trunk, it is the stem, and the stem is also called the staff.🔽The branches that grow from the trunk are the branches, and the branches that grow from the trunk are the rafters.

original: jaṭāḥ śirās tasya kilāvarohāḥ śākhā śiphā majjani sāram āhuḥ // /
analyzed: jaṭāḥ sirāḥ tasya kila avarohāḥ śākhā śiphāḥ majjani sāram āhuḥ
translated: The tufts of hair on the head are said to be the downward-growing branches, and the pith in the branches is said to be the essence.

original: niṣkuṭaṃ koṭaraṃ proktaṃ tvaci valkaṃ tu valkalam /
analyzed: niṣkuṭam koṭaram proktam tvaci valkam tu valkalam
translated: The hollow in the trunk is said to be the hollow, and the bark is the bark.

analyzed: nava puṣpa āḍhya śākhā agre vallarī mañjarī tathā
translated: The creeper with fresh flowers at the tip of the branch is also the cluster of flowers.

original: parṇaṃ patraṃ dalaṃ barhaṃ palāśaṃ chadanaṃ chadaḥ /
analyzed: parṇam patram dalam barham palāśam chadanam chadaḥ
translated: The leaf is the leaf, petal, plume, palāśa, covering, and cover.

original: syāt pallavaḥ kiśalayaḥ prabālaḥ pallavaṃ navam // /
analyzed: syāt pallavaḥ kiśalayaḥ prabālaḥ pallavam navam
translated: The tender leaf is the new sprout, and the tender leaf is the fresh sprout.

original: vistāro viṭapaḥ proktaḥ prāgraṃ tu śikharaṃ śiraḥ /
analyzed: vistāraḥ viṭapaḥ proktaḥ prāgram tu śikharam śiraḥ
translated: The spread is said to be the branch, and the top is the peak, the head.

analyzed: māḍhiḥ parṇaśirāḥ jñeyā vṛntam prasava bandhanam
translated: The cluster of leaves should be known as the māḍhi, and the stalk is the bond of the fruit.

analyzed: kula kṣāraka jālaka kalikāḥ tu kuḍamale kathitāḥ
translated: The net, bud, and bud are said to be the flower cup.

original: kusumaṃ sumanaḥ prasūnaprasavasumaṃ sūnuphullapuṣpaṃ syāt // /🔽makarando marandaś ca madhu puṣparasāhvayam /
analyzed: kusumam sumanaḥ prasūna prasava sumam sūnu phulla puṣpam syāt
translated: Kusuma, Sumanas, Prasuna, Prasava, Suman, Suna, Phulla, Pushpa are synonyms for flower.🔽Makaranda and Maranda are synonyms for honey, which is called Pushpa Rasa (flower juice).

original: pauṣpaṃ rajaḥ parāgaḥ syān madhulī dhūlikā ca sā // /🔽guccho guluñchaḥ stavako gucchakaḥ kusumoccayaḥ /🔽samaṃ parimalāmodagandhasaurabhyasaurabham // /
analyzed: pauṣpam rajaḥ parāgaḥ syāt madhulī dhūlikā ca sā             samam parimala āmoda gandha saurabhya saurabham
translated: Paraga is the pollen of flowers, and Madhuli and Dhulaika are synonyms for it.🔽Gulunchha, Stavaka, Guchchhaka, Kusumochchhaya, and Guchchha are synonyms for a cluster of flowers.🔽Pari, Mala, Amooda, Gandha, Saurabhya, and Saurabha are synonyms for fragrance.

original: ujjṛmbhitam ujjṛmbhaṃ smitam unmiṣitaṃ vinidram unnidram /🔽unmīlitaṃ vijṛmbhitam udbuddhodbhidurabhinnam udbhinnam // /
analyzed: ujjṛmbhitam ujjṛmbham smitam unmiṣitam vinidram unnidram  unmīlitam vijṛmbhitam udbuddha udbhiduḥ abhinnam udbhinnam
translated: Ujrimbita, Ujrimbha, Smita, Unmisha, Vinidra, Unnidra,🔽Unmishita, Vijrimbhita, Udbuddha, Udbhidura, Abhinna, and Udbhinna are synonyms for blossomed.

analyzed: vikasita hasita vikasvara vikaca vyākośa phulla samphullam
translated: Vikashita, Hasita, Vikaswara, Vikacha, Vyakosha, Phulla, Sampulla,

analyzed: sphuṭam udita dalita dīrṇa sphuṭita utphulla praphullam ekārtham
translated: Sphota, Udita, Dalita, Dirna, Sphotita, Utpulla, and Praphulla are synonyms for fully blossomed.

original: nidrāṇaṃ mudritaṃ suptaṃ militaṃ mīlitaṃ natam /
translated: Nidrana, Mudrita, Supta, Milita, Milshita, Nata,

analyzed: nikūṇitam saṅkucitam sa nidram alasam samam
translated: Nikunita, Sankuchita, Sanyidra, Alasa, and Sama are synonyms for closed.

original: āhus tarūṇāṃ phalam atra śasyaṃ tad āmam uktaṃ hi śalāṭusaṃjñam /
analyzed: āhuḥ tarūṇām phalam atra śasyam tat āmam uktam hi śalāṭu saṃjñam
translated: Here, the fruit of trees is said to be shashya, and that which is unripe is said to be called shalatu.

original: śuṣkaṃ tu vānaṃ pravadanti gulmastambau prakāṇḍairahito mahījaḥ // /🔽ulapaṃ gulminī vīrullatā vallī pratāninī /
analyzed: śuṣkam tu vānam pravadanti gulma stambau prakāṇḍaiḥ ahitaḥ mahījaḥ  ulapam gulminī vīrullatā vallī pratāninī
translated: But dry wood is said to be a shrub. A tree born from the earth is without branches.🔽A creeper is a shrub, a creeper is a vine, a creeper is a creeper, a creeper is a creeper.

original: vratatiḥ pratatiś caiṣā vistīrṇā vīrud ucyate // /
analyzed: vratatiḥ pratatiḥ ca eṣā vistīrṇā vīrudh ucyate
translated: This creeper is said to be extensive.

analyzed: atha vakṣāmi nakṣatra vṛkṣān āgama lakṣitān
translated: Now I will tell the constellation trees, marked by the coming of the serpent.

original: pūjyān āyuṣyadāṃś caiva varddhanāt pālanād api // /
analyzed: pūjyān āyuṣya dān ca eva varddhanāt pālanāt api
translated: To be worshipped, giving longevity, by nourishing and protecting.

analyzed: viṣa dru dhātrī taru hema dugdhāḥ jambūḥ tathā khādira kṛṣṇa vaṃśāḥ
translated: The poison tree, the nurse tree, the gold-milking tree, the rose-apple tree, the catechu tree, the black bamboo,

original: aśvatthanāgau ca vaṭaḥ palāśaḥ plakṣas tathāmbaṣṭhataruḥ krameṇa // /
analyzed: aśvattha nāgau ca vaṭaḥ palāśaḥ plakṣaḥ tathā ambaṣṭha taruḥ krameṇa
translated: The holy fig tree, the snake tree, the banyan tree, the palasha tree, the fig tree, and the ambashta tree in order.

analyzed: bilva arjunau ca eva sa kesarāḥ śambara sarja vañjulāḥ
translated: The bilva tree, the arjuna tree, the vikankata tree, the kesara tree, the shambara tree, the sarja tree, the jujube tree,

original: sapānasārkāś ca śamīkadambās tathāmranimbau madhukadrumaḥ kramāt // /
analyzed: sa pānasa arkāḥ ca śamī kadambāḥ tathā āmra nimbau madhuka drumaḥ kramāt
translated: The breadfruit tree, the sun tree, the shami tree, the bamboo tree, the mango tree, the neem tree, and the madhuka tree in order.

analyzed: amī nakṣatra daivatyāḥ vṛkṣāḥ syuḥ saptaviṃśatiḥ
translated: These are the twenty-seven trees that are presided over by the constellations.
This is the sequence of the constellations, beginning with Ashvini.

original: yas tv eteṣām ātmajanmarkṣabhājāṃ martyaḥ kuryād bheṣajādīn madāndhaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ tu eteṣām ātma janma ṛkṣa bhājām martyaḥ kuryāt bheṣaja ādīn mada andhaḥ
translated: But a man who, blinded by intoxication, would perform medical treatments and other things for those who have the constellation of their birth among these,

original: tasyāyuṣyaṃ śrīkalatraṃ ca putro naśyaty eṣā vardhate varddhanādyaiḥ // /
analyzed: tasya āyuṣyam śrī kalatram ca putraḥ naśyati eṣā vardhate varddhana ādyaiḥ
translated: His lifespan, prosperity, wife, and son are destroyed, and this increases with the Vardhanas and others.

original: ācāryoktau sphuṭam atha bṛhatsuśrute nāradīye nārāyaṇyāṃ kvacid api tathānyatra tantrāntareṣu /
analyzed: ācārya uktau sphuṭam atha bṛhatsuśrute nāradīye nārāyaṇyām kvacid api tathā anyatra tantra antareṣu
translated: The clear statements of the teacher, the great Sushruta, Narada, Narayana, and elsewhere in other Tantras,

original: jñātvāpīha prathitabhiṣajā nātidṛṣṭopayogaṃ naivāsmābhir viśaditam idaṃ gauravād granthabhīteḥ // /
analyzed: jñātvā api iha prathita bhiṣajā na ati dṛṣṭa upayogam na eva asmābhiḥ viśaditam idam gauravāt grantha bhīteḥ
translated: Even knowing this, it has not been clarified by us, out of fear of the bulk of the text, due to not seeing much use of it by famous physicians here.

original: tālādyā jātayaḥ sarvāḥ kramukaḥ ketakī tathā /
analyzed: tāla ādyāḥ jātayaḥ sarvāḥ kramukaḥ ketakī tathā
translated: All the species beginning with tala, the ketaki,
The date palm, coconut palm, and others are declared to be tall trees.

original: sarvāāṃro cārdrāṇi navaueṣadhāni suvīryyavantīti vadanti dhīrāḥ /
analyzed: ca ārdrāṇi nava oṣadhāni su vīryyavanti iti vadanti dhīrāḥ
translated: The wise say that all the new and moist herbs have great potency.

original: sarvāriya śuṣkāriya tu madhyamāni śuṣkāṇi jeīrṇāni ca niṣphalāni // /
analyzed: tu madhyamāni śuṣkāṇi jeīrṇāni ca niṣphalāni
translated: All the dry ones are of medium potency, and the very dry and old ones are fruitless.

analyzed: vāstūka kuṭaja guḍūcī vāsā kuṣmāṇḍaka ādi śatapatrī
translated: The vaastu, kutaja, guduchi, vasaka, pumpkin, and other hundred-petaled flowers,

original: ityādi tu nityārdraṃ guṇavac chuṣkaṃ yadā tadā dvimuyaṇam /🔽viḍaṅga madhu magūrī dāḍimaṃ pippalo guḍuḥ /
analyzed: ityādi tu nitya ārdram guṇavat śuṣkam yadā tadā  viḍaṅga madhu magūrī dāḍimam pippalaḥ guḍuḥ
translated: And so on, are always moist and have good qualities. When dry, they are of two types.🔽Vidanga, honey, magooree, pomegranate, fig, guduchi,
Snake-gourd, moonseed, rice, and others are considered to be of superior quality when old.

original: kāṭhinyaṃ madhyakāṭhinyaṃ mārdavaṃ ceti tu tridhā /
analyzed: kāṭhinyam madhya kāṭhinyam mārdavam ca iti tu tridhā
translated: Hardness, medium hardness, and softness - these are the three types.

original: dravyāṇām iha sarveṣāṃ prakṛtiḥ kathyate budhaiḥ // /
analyzed: dravyāṇām iha sarveṣām prakṛtiḥ kathyate budhaiḥ
translated: The nature of all substances here is described by the wise.

original: dravyāṇāṃ santi sarveṣāṃ pūrvair uktās trayo guṇāḥ /
analyzed: dravyāṇām santi sarveṣām pūrvaiḥ uktāḥ trayaḥ guṇāḥ
translated: All substances have three qualities mentioned by the ancients.

original: raso vīryaṃ vipākaś ca jñātavyās te 'tiyatnataḥ // /
analyzed: rasaḥ vīryam vipākaḥ ca jñātavyāḥ te tiyatnataḥ
translated: Taste, potency, and post-digestive effect should be known by them with great effort.

original: rasas tu madhurādiḥ syād vīryaṃ kāryasamarthatā /
analyzed: rasaḥ tu madhura ādiḥ syāt vīryam kārya samartha tā
translated: Taste should be sweet etc., potency is the ability to produce effects,

analyzed: pariṇāme guṇa āḍhya tvam vipākaḥ iti saṃjñitam
translated: and the abundance of qualities in the post-digestive state is called post-digestive effect.

original: śītam uṣṇaṃ ca rūkṣaṃ ca snigdhaṃ tīkṣṇaṃ tathā mṛdu /
analyzed: śītam uṣṇam ca rūkṣam ca snigdham tīkṣṇam tathā mṛdu
translated: Cold, hot, rough, unctuous, sharp, mild,

original: picchilaṃ viśadaṃ ceti vīryam aṣṭavidhaṃ smṛtam // /
analyzed: picchilam viśadam ca iti vīryam aṣṭavidham smṛtam
translated: slimy, and clear - potency is remembered to be of eight types.

original: niskuṭapramadakānanādiṣu dravyam etad api nirguṇaṃ bhavet /🔽kvāpyalīkavacanopakarṇanāt kvāpyasādhuvanitādisevanāt // /
analyzed: niskuṭa pramada kānana ādiṣu dravyam etat api nirguṇam bhavet  kvāpi alīka vacana upakarṇanāt kvāpi asādhu vanitā ādi sevanāt
translated: This substance would become devoid of qualities in gardens, pleasure groves, forests, etc.🔽Sometimes due to hearing false words, sometimes due to serving unchaste women, etc.

analyzed: jātam śmaśāne valmīke deśe mūtra ādi dūṣite
translated: Born in a cremation ground, an anthill, or a place polluted by urine, etc.,

analyzed: dravyam na eva upayogāya bhiṣajām upajāyate
translated: The substance is not suitable for use by physicians.

original: kandaṃ himartau śiśire ca mūlaṃ puṣpaṃ vasante guṇadaṃ vadanti /
analyzed: kandam hima ṛtau śiśire ca mūlam puṣpam vasante guṇa dam vadanti
translated: In the winter season, the bulb is said to be beneficial, in the cold season the root, and in the spring the flower is said to be beneficial.

analyzed: prabāla patrāṇi nidāgha kāle syuḥ paṅka jātāni śarad prayoge
translated: Coral leaves are in the summer season, and lotus flowers are in the autumn season.

analyzed: nimba uḍumbara jambava ādyāḥ yathākālam guṇa uttarāḥ
translated: Nimba, Udumbara, Jamva, etc. are superior in qualities according to the season.

original: kandādiṣv atha sarveṣāṃ pṛthag eva rasādyaḥ // /
analyzed: kanda ādiṣu atha sarveṣām pṛthak eva rasa ādyaḥ
translated: Now, in all the bulbous roots etc., the rasa (taste) etc. are different for each.

original: kecit kande ke 'pi mūleṣu kecit patre puṣpe ke 'pi kecit phaleṣu /
analyzed: kecid kande ke pi mūleṣu kecid patre puṣpe ke pi kecid phaleṣu
translated: Some are in the bulb, some in the roots, some in the leaves, some in the flowers, some in the fruits.

analyzed: tvaci eva anye valkale kecid ittham dravya stomāḥ bhinna bhinnam guṇa āḍhyāḥ
translated: Others are in the bark, some in the inner bark, thus the praises of the substances are different and full of qualities.

original: deśe deśe yojanadvādaśānte bhinnāny āhur dravyanāmāni loke /
analyzed: deśe deśe yojana dvādaśānte bhinnāni āhuḥ dravya nāmāni loke
translated: In every country, twelve yojanas apart, they say the names of substances are different in the world.

original: kiṃcāmīṣu prāṇināṃ varṇabhāṣāceṣṭācchāyā bhinnarūpā vibhāti // /🔽anirdiṣṭaprayogeṣu mūlaṃ grāhyaṃ tvagādiṣu /
analyzed: kiṃca amīṣu prāṇinām varṇa bhāṣā ceṣṭā chāyā bhinna rūpā vibhāti  a nirdiṣṭa prayogeṣu mūlam grāhyam tvac ādiṣu
translated: And in these, the shadow of the color, language, and behavior of living beings appears in a different form.🔽In unspecified preparations, the root should be taken from among the bark etc.

original: sāmānyoktau prayoktavyaṃ prāhus toyaṃ tu nābhasam // /
analyzed: sāmānya uktau prayoktavyam prāhuḥ toyam tu nābhasam
translated: In general statements, they say water should be used, but not water from the navel.

analyzed: cūrṇa kalka kaṣāyāṇām pramāṇam yatra na uditam
translated: Where the measure of powders, pastes, and decoctions is not mentioned,

analyzed: tatra dravya pramāṇena svayam buddhyā prayojayet
translated: there one should use one's own intelligence according to the measure of the substance.

analyzed: mādhvīkam sarva madyānām madhūnām mākṣikam tathā
translated: Honey wine is the best of all alcoholic drinks, and honey is the best of all sweet things.

analyzed: tailam tu tila sambhūtam dhātavaḥ vasti sambhavāḥ

analyzed: śālīnām raktaśāliḥ syāt sūpyānām mudgaḥ eva ca
translated: Oil is produced from sesame seeds, and the minerals are found in the bladder.🔽Among the rice varieties, red rice is the best, and among the soups, mung beans are the best.

original: mūlānāṃ pippalīmūlaṃ phalānāṃ madanaṃ phalam // /🔽tvacā tu gandhadravyāṇāṃ patrāṇāṃ gandhapatrakam /
analyzed: mūlānām pippalī mūlam phalānām madanam phalam  tvacā tu gandha dravyāṇām patrāṇām gandha patrakam
translated: Among the roots, long pepper root is the best, and among the fruits, the madana fruit is the best.🔽Among the fragrant substances, the bark is the best, and among the leaves, the fragrant leaf is the best.

analyzed: jīvanti śākam śākānām lavaṇānām ca saindhavam
translated: Among the vegetables, the jivanti vegetable is the best, and among the salts, rock salt is the best.

analyzed: sāmānya puṣpa nirdeśāt mālatī kusumam kṣipet
translated: Since the flowers are generally indicated, one should add jasmine flowers.

analyzed: ittham anye pi boddhavyāḥ prayogāḥ yoga lakṣitāḥ
translated: In this way, other practices should also be understood, as determined by yoga.

original: dravyaṃ vātaharaṃ yat tat sakalaṃ dīpanaṃ param /
analyzed: dravyam vāta haram yat tat sakalam dīpanam param
translated: That substance which subdues vata is the best stimulant for all.

analyzed: kapha hāri samam proktam pitta ghnam manda dīpanam  yat śīta vīryam guru pitta hāri dravyam nṛṇām vāta karam tat uktam
translated: That which subdues kapha is said to be equal, and that which subdues pitta is a mild stimulant.🔽That substance which is cold in potency, heavy and subdues pitta is said to cause vata in humans.

original: yaduṣṇavīryaṃ laghu vātahāri śleṣmāpahaṃ pittakaraṃ ca tat syāt // /
analyzed: yat uṣṇa vīryam laghu vāta hāri śleṣma apaham pitta karam ca tat syāt

translated: are described.

translated: the physician should practice in the kingdom of medicine, with a mind illuminated by the light of extremely subtle wisdom that has been accumulated without obstruction.

analyzed: iti eṣa vaidyaka vikalpa vidhā nidāna cūḍāmaṇau mṛḍa para āgama pārageṇa
translated: Thus, in the crest-jewel of the causes of the formulation of medical options, by Mṛḍapāragama,

analyzed: rājanighaṇṭu  guḍūcyādi varga
translated: Royal Lexicon.🔽The group beginning with Guduchi.

original: guḍūcī cātha mūrvā ca paṭolo 'raṇyajas tathā /
analyzed: guḍūcī ca atha mūrvā ca paṭolaḥ raṇyajaḥ tathā
translated: Guduchi, murva, patola, wild,

analyzed: kākolī ca dvidhā proktā māṣaparṇī tathā apare
translated: Two types of kakoli are mentioned, and also mashaparni.

Vandhyakarkoti is mentioned, katu tundya, and akhukarnica.

analyzed: dvidhā indravāruṇī ca atra yavatiktā īśvarā tathā
translated: Indivaru is of two types here, and also yavatikteshwari.

analyzed: moraṭaḥ ca atha ced indīvarā vastāntrikā ca sā
translated: Moraṭa, and if Indīvaras, then that is Tāntrikā.

analyzed: kaivartī tāmravallī ca kāṇḍīrī ca atha jantukā
translated: Kaivartī, and Tāmravallī, and Kāṇḍīrī, and then Jantu.

analyzed: amlaparṇī tathā śaṅkhapuṣpī ca āvartakī tathā
translated: Amlarpṇī, and Śaṅkhapūpī, and then Āvartī.

translated: Putradā, and Palāśī - these nine names should be known here.🔽In this way, the herbs not mentioned by the wise should be understood in order.

analyzed: asmin vīrudh varge nāmnā ca guṇaiḥ ca kīrtyante
translated: In this chapter on herbs, they are described by name and qualities.

translated: Even though in some places the rule of counting lost numbers is seen,

translated: Chinnodbhava, Amritalata, and Rasayani are also known as Chhinna, Somapalita, and Amritasambhava.

translated: The divine Harichandana is bitter and cold, and is difficult to obtain by humans here.🔽It removes heat, fatigue, dryness, and fainting like sandalwood.

analyzed: candanāni samānāni rasataḥ vīryataḥ tathā
translated: The Chandanas are similar in taste and potency.

analyzed: bhidyante kiṃtu gandhena tatra ādyam guṇavattaram
translated: But they are distinguished by their fragrance, among which the first is superior in quality.

original: devadāru suradāru dārukaṃ snigdhadārur amarādidāru ca /
analyzed: devadāru suradāru dārukam snigdhadāruḥ amara ādi dāru ca
translated: Devadaru, Suradaru, Daruka, Snigdhadaru, Amaradidaru,

original: bhadradāru śivadāru śāmbhavaṃ bhūtahāri bhavadāru rudravat // /🔽snigdhadāru smṛtaṃ tiktaṃ snigdhoṣṇaṃ śleṣmavātajit /
analyzed: snigdhadāru smṛtam tiktam snigdha uṣṇam śleṣma vāta jit
translated: Bhadradaru, Shivadaru, Shambhavam, Bhutaharin, Bhavadaru are like Rudra.🔽Snigdhadaru is known to be bitter, unctuous and hot, it conquers phlegm and wind.
It destroys indigestion, constipation, hemorrhoids, diabetes and fever.

analyzed: deva kāṣṭham pūti kāṣṭham bhadra kāṣṭham su kāṣṭhakam
translated: Devakashtham, Puttikashtham, Bhadrakashtham, Sukashthakam,

analyzed: ca eva
translated: Asnigdhadarukam, and Kashthadaru are the six names.

analyzed: devakāṣṭham tu tikta uṣṇam rūkṣam śleṣma anila apaham
translated: Devakashtham is bitter and hot, dry, and removes phlegm and wind.

analyzed: bhūta doṣa apaham dhatte liptam aṅgeṣu kālikam
translated: When applied to the body, it removes the faults of spirits and is effective against time.

analyzed: devadāru dvidhā jñeyam tatra ādyam snigdhadārukam
translated: Devadaru should be known as of two types - the first is snigdhadaru (smooth wood) and

original: dvitīyaṃ kāṣṭhadāru syād dvayor nāmāny abhedataḥ // /
analyzed: dvitīyam kāṣṭhadāru syāt dvayoḥ nāmāni abhedataḥ
translated: the second is kashthadaru (wooden). The two are not different in name.

original: cīḍā ca dārugandhā gandhavadhūr gandhamādanī taruṇī /
analyzed: cīḍā ca dārugandhā gandhavadhūḥ gandhamādanī taruṇī
translated: Cida, darugandha, gandhavadhu, gandhamadani, taruni,

original: tārā ca bhūtamārī maṅgalyā tu kapāṭinī grahabhītijit /
analyzed: tārā ca bhūtamārī maṅgalyā tu kapāṭinī grahabhītijit
translated: tara, bhutatari, mangalya, kapatini, grahabhutijit.

original: cīḍā kaṭūṣṇā kāsaghnī kaphajid dīpanī parā /
analyzed: cīḍā kaṭu uṣṇā kāsa ghnī kapha jit dīpanī parā
translated: Cida is pungent and hot, destroys cough, subdues kapha, and is an excellent stimulant.

original: atyantasevitā sā tu pittadoṣabhramāpahā // /🔽saptaparṇaḥ patravarṇaḥ śuktiparṇaḥ suparṇakaḥ /
analyzed: atyanta sevitā sā tu pitta doṣa bhrama apahā
translated: When used excessively, it removes the confusion caused by pitta dosha.🔽Saptaparna, patravarna, shuktiparna, suparnaka,
saptachada, gushchapusa, ayugmaparna, munichhada.
Brihattvak, bahuparna, and also shalmaliparnaka,
madagandha, gandhiparna should be known as coming from the fire region.

analyzed: saptaparṇaḥ tu tikta uṣṇaḥ tridoṣa ghnaḥ ca dīpanaḥ
translated: Saptaparna is bitter and hot, destroys the three doshas, and is a digestive stimulant.

analyzed: mada gandhaḥ nirunddhe yam vraṇa rakta āmaya krimīn
translated: Madagandha stops wounds, blood, diseases, and worms.

original: saralas tu pūtikāṣṭhaṃ tumbī pītadrur utthito dīpataruḥ /
analyzed: saralaḥ tu pūtikāṣṭham tumbī pītadruḥ utthitaḥ dīpataruḥ
translated: Sarala, puttikashtham, tumvi, peetadru, utthita, deepataru,

analyzed: sa snigdhadāru saṃjñaḥ snigdhaḥ mārīcapatrakaḥ navadhā
translated: That is known as fragrant wood, fragrant, and is of nine types.
Sarala is pungent, bitter, and hot, destroys phlegm and wind,

original: tvagdoṣaśophakaṇḍūtivraṇaghnaḥ koṣṭhaśuddhidaḥ // /🔽jñeyaṃ kuṅkumam agnisekharam asṛk kāśmīrajaṃ pītakaṃ kāśmīraṃ rudhiraṃ varaṃ ca piśunaṃ raktaṃ śaṭhaṃ śoṇitam /🔽vāhlīkaṃ ghusṛṇaṃ vareṇyam aruṇaṃ kāleyakaṃ jāguḍaṃ kāntaṃ vahniśikhaṃ ca kesaravaraṃ gauraṃ karākṣīritam // /
analyzed: jñeyam kuṅkumam agnisekharam asṛk kāśmīrajam pītakam kāśmīram rudhiram varam ca piśunam raktam śaṭham śoṇitam  vāhlīkam ghusṛṇam vareṇyam aruṇam kāleyakam jāguḍam kāntam vahniśikham ca kesaravaram gauram kara akṣi īritam
translated: Cures skin diseases, swelling, itching, and wounds, and gives purification of the abdomen.🔽Saffron should be known as Agnisekhara, Kashmiri blood, yellow, Kashmiri, excellent blood, Pishuna, red, Shonita,🔽Vahlika, Ghushana, excellent, red, Kalaya, Jaguda, beloved, fire-flame, the best of filaments, white, and milk-colored.

analyzed: kuṅkumam surabhi tikta kaṭu uṣṇam kāsa vāta kapha kaṇṭha rujā ghnam
translated: Saffron is fragrant, bitter, pungent, and hot, destroys cough, wind, phlegm, and throat pain,

analyzed: mūrdha śūla viṣa doṣa nāśanam rocanam ca tanu kānti kārakam
translated: Cures headaches and poisons, is appetizing, and gives a clear complexion.

original: tṛṇakuṅkumaṃ tṛṇāsraṃ gandhitṛṇaṃ śoṇitaṃ ca tṛṇapuṣpam /
analyzed: tṛṇakuṅkumam tṛṇāsram gandhitṛṇam śoṇitam ca tṛṇapuṣpam
translated: Grass saffron, grass blood, fragrant grass, red grass flower,

original: gandhādhikaṃ tṛṇotthaṃ tṛṇagauraṃ lohitaṃ ca navasaṃjñam // /🔽tṛṇakuṅkumaṃ kaṭūṣṇaṃ kaphamārutaśophanut /
analyzed: gandhādhikam tṛṇottham tṛṇagauram lohitam ca nava saṃjñam
translated: More fragrant, grass-born, grass-white, and red are the nine names.🔽Grass saffron is pungent and hot, destroys phlegm, wind, and swelling,

analyzed: kaṇḍūti pāmā kuṣṭha āma doṣa ghnam bhāskaram param
translated: Cures itching, scabies, leprosy, and other diseases, and is excellent for the sun.
Priyangu, Phalini, Shyama, Priyavalli, Phalapriya,

original: gaurī govandanī vṛttā kārambhā kaṅgu kaṅgunī // /🔽bhaṅgurā gauravallī ca subhagā parṇabhedinī /
analyzed: bhaṅgurā gauravallī ca subhagā parṇabhedinī
translated: Gouri, Govandani, Vritta, Karambha, Kangu, Kanguini,🔽Bhangura, Gauravalli, Subhaga, Parnabhedini,

original: śubhā pītā ca maṅgalyā śreyasī cāṅkabhūmitā // /🔽priyaṅguḥ śītalā tiktā dāhapittāsradoṣajit /
analyzed: śubhā pītā ca maṅgalyā śreyasī ca aṅka bhū mitā
translated: Subha, Pita, Mangalya, Shreyasi, and Ankhabhumita,🔽Priyangu is cold, bitter, and conquers burning sensation, pitta, blood disorders,
Vomiting, giddiness, and fever, and destroys stiffness of the mouth.
Kasturi, Mrignabi, Madani, Gandhachelika,

analyzed: vedhamukhyā ca mārjārī subhagā bahugandhadā
translated: Vedhamukhya, Marjari, Subhaga, Bahugandhada,
Sahasravedhi, Shyama, Kamand, Mrigandaja,
Kuranganahi, Lalita, Mada, Mrigamanda,
Shyamali, and Kamomudi - should be known by these eighteen names.
Kasturi is fragrant, bitter, good for the eyes, and cures mouth diseases,
It removes leprosy, phlegm, bad smell, wind, inauspiciousness, and impurities.

original: kapilā piṅgalā kṛṣṇā kastūrī trividhā kramāt /
analyzed: kapilā piṅgalā kṛṣṇā kastūrī trividhā kramāt
translated: Kasturi is of three types - Kapila, Pingala, and Krishna, in order.

original: nepāle 'pi ca kāśmīre kāmarūpe ca jāyate // /
analyzed: nepāle pi ca kāśmīre kāmarūpe ca jāyate
translated: It is found in Nepal, Kashmir, and Kamarupa.

original: sāpy ekā kharikā tataś ca tilakā jñeyā kulitthāparā piṇḍānyāpi ca nāyiketi ca parā yā pañcabhedābhidhā /
analyzed: sā api ekā kharikā tatas ca tilakā jñeyā kulitthā aparā piṇḍā anyā api ca nāyikā iti ca parā yā pañca bheda abhidhā
translated: That same Kharikā is then known as Tilaka, and another is Kulitthakā, and also Piṇḍikā, and the next one is Nāyikā, which has five different names.

original: sā śuddhā mṛganābhitaḥ kramavaśād eṣā kṣitīśocitā pakṣatyādidinatrayeṣu janitā kastūrikā stūyate // /
analyzed: sā śuddhā mṛganābhitaḥ krama vaśāt eṣā kṣitīśa ucitā pakṣati ādi dina trayeṣu janitā kastūrikā stūyate
translated: That is pure, and from musk, this is fit for kings, and the musk produced on the three days beginning with the day after the fortnight, is praised.

original: cūrṇākṛtis tu kharikā tilakā tilābhā kaulatthabījasadṛśī ca kulitthakā ca /
analyzed: cūrṇa ākṛtiḥ tu kharikā tilakā tilābhā kaulattha bīja sadṛśī ca kulitthakā ca
translated: But Kharikā is in the form of powder, Tilaka is like a sesame seed, and Kulitthakā is like a Kulattha seed.

original: sthūlā tataḥ kiyad iyaṃ kila piṇḍikākhyā tasyāś ca kiṃcid adhikā yadi nāyikā sā // /
analyzed: sthūlā tatas kiyat iyam kila piṇḍikā ākhyā tasyāḥ ca kiṃcid adhikā yadi nāyikā sā
translated: Then this is said to be slightly larger than that, and if it is slightly larger than that, it is Nāyikā.

original: svāde tiktā piñjarā ketakīnāṃ gandhaṃ dhatte lāghavaṃ tolane ca /
analyzed: svāde tiktā piñjarā ketakīnām gandham dhatte lāghavam tolane ca
translated: It is bitter in taste, tawny, and has the smell of ketaki flowers, and is light when weighed.

original: yāpsu nyastā naiva vaivarṇyam īyāt kastūrī sā rājabhogyāpraśastā // /
analyzed: yā apsu nyastā nā eva vaivarṇyam īyāt kastūrī sā rāja bhogyā praśastā
translated: When placed in water, it does not turn color, that musk is fit for kings and is not praised.

original: yā gandhaṃ ketakīnām apaharati madaṃ sindhurāṇāṃ ca varṇe svāde tiktā kaṭur vā laghur atha tulitā marditā cikkaṇā syāt /
analyzed: yā gandham ketakīnām apaharati madam sindhurāṇām ca varṇe svāde tiktā kaṭuḥ vā laghuḥ atha tulitā marditā cikkaṇā syāt
translated: That which removes the smell of ketaki flowers and the color of Sindhu's intoxication, is bitter or pungent in taste, light when weighed, and sticky when pressed,

original: dāhaṃ yā naiti vahnau śimiśimiti ciraṃ carmagandhā hutāśe sā kastūrī praśastā varamṛgatanujā rājate rājabhogyā // /
analyzed: dāham yā nā eti vahnau ciram carmagandhā hutāśe sā kastūrī praśastā vara mṛga tanujā rājate rāja bhogyā  /
translated: That musk which does not burn in fire, which emits a crackling sound for a long time, and which smells like leather when burnt in fire, is considered excellent. The musk produced from the body of a deer is praised as fit for kings.

original: bāle jarati ca hariṇe kṣīṇe rogiṇi ca mandagandhayutā /
analyzed: bāle jarati ca hariṇe kṣīṇe rogiṇi ca manda gandha yutā
translated: In a young girl, an old woman, a deer, a weak person, a sick person, it has a faint smell.

original: kāmāture ca taruṇe kastūrī bahulaparimalā bhavati // /
analyzed: kāma āture ca taruṇe kastūrī bahula parimalā bhavati
translated: But in a young man who is passionate, musk has a strong fragrance.

original: yā snigdhā dhūmagandhā vahati vinihitā pītatāṃ pāthaso 'ntar niḥśeṣaṃ yā niviṣṭā bhavati hutavahe bhasmasād eva sadyaḥ /
analyzed: yā snigdhā dhūma gandhā vahati vinihitā pīta tām pāthasaḥ ntar niḥśeṣam yā niviṣṭā bhavati hutavahe bhasmasāt eva sadyas
translated: That which is oily, smells like smoke, when placed inside water takes a yellow color, and when completely put into fire, immediately becomes ash,

original: yā ca nyastā tulāyāṃ kalayati gurutāṃ marditā rūkṣatāṃ ca jñeyā kastūrikeyaṃ khalu kṛtamatibhiḥ kṛtrimā naiva sevyā // /
analyzed: yā ca nyastā tulāyām kalayati guru tām marditā rūkṣa tām ca jñeyā kastūrikā iyam khalu kṛtamatibhiḥ kṛtrimā nā eva sevyā  /
translated: and when placed on a scale, weighs heavy, and when crushed, is rough, this musk should be known as artificial by the wise and should not be used at all.

original: śuddho vā malino 'stu vā mṛgamadaḥ kiṃ jātam etāvatā ko 'py asyānavadhiś camatkṛtinidhiḥ saurabhyam eko guṇaḥ /
analyzed: śuddhaḥ vā malinaḥ stu vā mṛgamadaḥ kim jātam etāvatā kaḥ pi asya anavadhiḥ camatkṛti nidhiḥ saurabhyam ekaḥ guṇaḥ
translated: Whether pure or impure, what is the use of musk? It is just a storehouse of endless wonders, the only quality is its fragrance.

original: yenāsau smaramaṇḍanaikavasatir bhāle kapole gale dormūle kucamaṇḍale ca kurute saṅgaṃ kuraṅgīdṛśām // /
analyzed: yena asau smara maṇḍana eka vasatiḥ bhāle kapole gale dormūle kuca maṇḍale ca kurute saṅgam kuraṅgī dṛśām
translated: By which it becomes associated with the eyes of the deer-eyed women on the forehead, cheeks, throat, base of the arms, and on the circle of the breasts, being the sole ornament of Cupid.

original: gorocanā ruciḥ śobhā rucirā śobhanā śubhā /
analyzed: gorocanā ruciḥ śobhā rucirā śobhanā śubhā
translated: Gorocana (cow's bile) is called Ruci (lustrous), Sobha (splendor), Rucira (beautiful), Sobhana (adorning), and Svaha (good).

original: gaurī ca rocanā piṅgā maṅgalyā piṅgalā śivā // /
analyzed: gaurī ca rocanā piṅgā maṅgalyā piṅgalā śivā
translated: It is also called Gauri (white), Rocana (purifying), Pingala (tawny), Mangalya (auspicious), and Shiva (benign).

original: pītā ca gautamī gavyā vandanīyā ca kāñcanī /
analyzed: pītā ca gautamī gavyā vandanīyā ca kāñcanī
translated: It is also called Pita (yellow), Gautami (of Gautama), Gavya (cow-related), Vandaneya (worthy of worship), Kanchana (golden),
Medhya (purifying), Manorama (charming), Shyama (dark), Rama (pleasing), Bhumi (earth), and Kara (hand).

original: gorocanā ca śiśirā viṣadoṣahantrī rucyā ca pācanakarī krimikuṣṭhahantrī /
analyzed: gorocanā ca śiśirā viṣa doṣa hantrī rucyā ca pācana karī krimi kuṣṭha hantrī
translated: Gorocana is cool, destroys the ill effects of poison, is appetizing, digestive, and cures worms and skin diseases.

original: bhūtagrahopaśamanaṃ kurute ca pathyā śṛṅgāramaṅgalakarī janamohinī ca // /
analyzed: bhūta graha upaśamanam kurute ca pathyā śṛṅgāra maṅgala karī jana mohinī ca
translated: It alleviates demonic possession, is wholesome, causes passion and auspiciousness, and enchants people.

original: karpūro ghanasārakaḥ sitakaraḥ śītaḥ śaśāṅkaḥ śilā śītāṃśur himavālukā himakaraḥ śītaprabhaḥ śāmbhavaḥ /
translated: Camphor is called Ganasara (best of the group), Sitakara (white-rayed), Sita (cool), Sasankah (having the moon), Shila (stone), Sitamshu (cool-rayed), Himavaluka (snowy sand), Himas (snow), Sita (white), Prabha (light), Sambhava (related to Shiva),

analyzed: śubhrāṃśuḥ sphaṭikā abhra sāra mihikā tārābhra candra indavaḥ candrāloka tuṣāragaura kumudāni ekādaśa āhvā dviśas
translated: Shubhramshu (white-rayed), Sphatika (crystal), Abhra (cloud), Sāra (essence), Mihika (mist), Tārā (star), Abhra (cloud), Chandra (moon), Indhu (moon), Chandraloka (moonlight), Tusara (snow), Gaura (white), Kumuda (white lotus), and Ekādaśāhva (having eleven names).

original: potāso bhīmasenas tadanu sitakaraḥ śaṃkarāvāsasaṃjñaḥ prāṃśuḥ piñjo 'bdasāras tadanu himayutā vālukā jūṭikā ca /
analyzed: potāsaḥ bhīmasenaḥ tadanu sitakaraḥ śaṃkarāvāsa saṃjñaḥ prāṃśuḥ piñjaḥ bdasāraḥ tadanu himayutā vālukā jūṭikā ca
translated: It is also called Potāsa (alkali), Bhīmasena (terrible army), Sitakara (white-rayed), Śaṅkarāvāsa (abode of Śiva), Prāśu (tall), Piñja (tawny), Abdasāra (essence of the year), and Himayukā (having snow), Vālukā (sand), and Jūtikā (shining).

original: paścād asyās tuṣāras tadupari sahimaḥ śītalaḥ pakvikānyā karpūrasyeti bhedā guṇarasamahasāṃ vaidyadṛśyena dṛśyāḥ // /
analyzed: paścāt asyāḥ tuṣāraḥ tat upari sa himaḥ śītalaḥ pakvikā anyā karpūrasya iti bhedāḥ guṇa rasa mahasām vaidya dṛśyena dṛśyāḥ  /
translated: After that, there is snow, then snow with ice, then the cold season, and then the powder of camphor. These are to be seen by the eye of a physician, as they are the differences in the great qualities and tastes.

analyzed: karpūraḥ nūtanaḥ tiktaḥ snigdhaḥ ca uṣṇaḥ sra dāha daḥ
translated: Fresh camphor is bitter, unctuous, hot, and causes bleeding and burning.

original: cirastho dāhadoṣaghnaḥ sa dhautaḥ śubhakṛt paraḥ // /
analyzed: cirasthaḥ dāha doṣa ghnaḥ sa dhautaḥ śubha kṛt paraḥ
translated: Camphor that has been stored for a long time removes burning and other defects, and when washed, it becomes extremely auspicious.

original: śiro madhyaṃ talaṃ ceti karpūras trividhaḥ smṛtaḥ /🔽śiraḥ stambhāgrasaṃjātaṃ madhyaṃ parṇatale talam // /🔽bhāsvadviśadapulakaṃ śirojātaṃ tu madhyamam /
analyzed: śiraḥ madhyam talam ca iti karpūraḥ trividhaḥ smṛtaḥ  śiraḥ stambha agra saṃjātam madhyam parṇa tale talam  bhāsvat viśada pulakam śiraḥ jātam tu madhyamam
translated: Camphor is known to be of three types: head, middle, and base.🔽The head is produced at the top of the stem, the middle is on the leaf surface, and the base is at the base.🔽The head camphor is shiny, clear, and has fine pores, while the middle one is shiny and clear.

original: sāmānyapulakaṃ svacchaṃ tale cūrṇaṃ tu gaurakam // /
analyzed: sāmānya pulakam svaccham tale cūrṇam tu gaurakam
translated: The base camphor is clear and white, and the powder is pale.

analyzed: stambha garbha sthitam śreṣṭham stambha bāhye ca madhyamam
translated: The camphor located in the heart of the stem is the best, that on the outside of the stem is medium,

original: svaccham īṣat haridrābhaṃ śubhraṃ tan madhyamaṃ smṛtam sudṛḍhaṃ śubhrarūkṣaṃ ca pulakaṃ bāhyajaṃ vadet // /
analyzed: svaccham īṣat haridrā ābham śubhram tat madhyamam smṛtam su dṛḍham śubhra rūkṣam ca pulakam bāhya jam vadet  /
translated: and that which is clear, slightly yellowish, and white is considered medium. One should say that the camphor with fine pores and white roughness is produced from the outside.

original: svacchaṃ bhṛṅgārapattraṃ laghutaraviśadaṃ tolane tiktakaṃ cet svāde śaityaṃ suhṛdyaṃ bahalaparimalāmodasaurabhyadāyi /
analyzed: svaccham bhṛṅgāra pattram laghutara viśadam tolane tiktakam ced svāde śaityam suhṛdyam bahala parimala āmoda saurabhya dāyi
translated: If the camphor is clear, with the color of a bee's wing, light, easily weighed, bitter to taste, cool to the touch, pleasant, and gives off a thick, fragrant, sweet smell,

original: niḥsnehaṃ dārḍhyapattraṃ śubhataram iti cet rājayogyaṃ praśastaṃ karpūraṃ cānyathā ced bahutaram aśane sphoṭadāyi vraṇāya // /
analyzed: niḥsneham dārḍhya pattram śubhataram iti ced rāja yogyam praśastam karpūram ca anyathā ced bahutaram aśane sphoṭa dāyi vraṇāya
translated: if it is free from oil, hard, and beautiful, then it is fit for a king and is praised. But if it is otherwise, it may cause blisters and wounds if eaten in large quantities.
Chinese camphor, artificial camphor, white camphor, pungent camphor,

original: meghasāras tuṣāraś ca dvīpakarpūrajaḥ smṛtaḥ // /🔽cīnakaḥ kaṭutiktoṣṇa īṣacchītaḥ kaphāpahaḥ /
translated: and camphor from the island are known as snow essence and cloud essence.🔽Chinese camphor is pungent, bitter, hot, slightly cool, and removes phlegm.

translated: Lead is the best for quickly purifying silver.🔽Lead is of nine types: Reeti, Kshudrasuvama, Singhalaka, Pingalaka, Pitalaka,

original: lauhitakam ārakuṭṭaṃ piṅgalalohaṃ ca pītakaṃ navadhā // /
analyzed: lauhitakam ārakuṭṭam piṅgalaloham ca pītakam navadhā
translated: Lohitaka, Arakuta, Pingalaloha, and Pitaka.
Rajareeti, Kakatundika, Rajaputri, Maheswari,

analyzed: brāhmaṇī brahmarītiḥ ca kapilā piṅgalā api ca
translated: Brahmani, Brahmareeti, Kapila, and Pingala.🔽The two types of lead are bitter, cold, and salty in taste.

analyzed: śodhanam pāṇḍu vāta ghnam krimi plīha ārti pitta jit
translated: It purifies, cures anemia and wind disorders, and conquers worms, spleen disease, and bile.

original: śuddhā snigdhā mṛduḥ śītā suraṅgā sūtrapattriṇī /
analyzed: śuddhā snigdhā mṛduḥ śītā su raṅgā sūtrapattriṇī
translated: Pure, oily, soft, cold, well-colored, suitable for wires and foils,

analyzed: hema upamā śubhā svacchā janyā rītiḥ prakīrtitā
translated: The brass known as Hema, Upamā, Śubhā, Svachchā, and Janyā is declared to be of good quality.
Brass, Saurashtra, Ghosa, Kamsīya, Vahnila, and Lohā are synonyms.

original: dīptaṃ lohaṃ ghorapuṣpaṃ dīptakaṃ sumanāhvayam // /🔽kāṃsyaṃ tu tiktam uṣṇaṃ cakṣuṣyaṃ vātakaphavikāraghnam /
analyzed: kāṃsyam tu tiktam uṣṇam cakṣuṣyam vāta kapha vikāra ghnam
translated: Brass is said to be of seven types: Dīpta, Lohā, Ghora-puṣpa, Dīptaka, and Sumana.🔽Brass is bitter, hot, good for the eyes, and destroys disorders of vāta and kapha.

analyzed: rūkṣam kaṣāya rucyam laghu dīpana pācanam pathyam
translated: It is dry, astringent, light, appetizing, digestive, and wholesome.

original: śvetaṃ dīptaṃ mṛdu jyotiḥ śabdāḍhyaṃ snigdhanirmalam /
analyzed: śvetam dīptam mṛdu jyotiḥ śabda āḍhyam snigdha nirmalam
translated: White, shining, soft, luminous, sound-rich, glossy, and clear,

analyzed: ghana agni saha sūtra aṅgam kāṃsyam uttamam īritam
translated: able to withstand dense fire and having a wire-like structure - such brass is said to be of the highest quality.
Vartaloha, Vartatīkṣṇa, Vartataka, and Lohasaṅkara are synonyms.
Nīlikā, Nīlalohā, and Lohaja are synonyms for Vaddhalohā.

original: idaṃ lohaṃ kaṭūṣṇaṃ ca tiktaṃ ca śiśiraṃ tathā /
analyzed: idam loham kaṭu uṣṇam ca tiktam ca śiśiram tathā
translated: This iron is bitter, hot, and cold,

analyzed: kapha hṛt pitta śamanam madhuram dāha meha nud
translated: removes kapha, pacifies pitta, is sweet, and alleviates burning and diabetes.
Aśmāntika, Kānthalohā, Kānti, and Lohāka are synonyms.

analyzed: kāntāyasam kṛṣṇaloham mahāloham ca saptadhā
translated: Kānti, Kānti, Kṛṣṇalohā, and Mahālohā are the seven types of iron.

original: syād bhrāmakaṃ tadanu cumbakaromakākhyaṃ syāc chedakākhyam iti tac ca caturvidhaṃ syāt /🔽kāntāśmalohaguṇavṛddhi yathākrameṇa dārḍhyāṅgakāntikacakārṣṇyavirogadāyi // /
analyzed: syāt bhrāmakam tadanu cumbaka romaka ākhyam syāt chedaka ākhyam iti tat ca caturvidham syāt  kānta aśma loha guṇa vṛddhi yathākrameṇa dārḍhya aṅga kānti kaca kārṣṇya viroga dāyi
translated: It may be a whirler, a lip-kissing, a cutter, and so on, and it may be of four kinds.🔽The increase of the qualities of the lover's stone gives firmness, beauty, blackness, and freedom from disease in order.

analyzed: ayaskānta viśeṣāḥ syuḥ bhrāmakāḥ cumbaka ādayaḥ
translated: The special iron-loving stones are the whirlers, lip-kissers, and so on.

analyzed: rasāyana karāḥ sarve deha siddhi karāḥ parāḥ
translated: All of them produce elixirs, and are supreme in bringing about bodily perfection.

original: na sūtena vinā kāntaṃ na kāntena vinā rasaḥ /
analyzed: na sūtena vinā kāntam na kāntena vinā rasaḥ
translated: There is no lover's stone without mercury, and no elixir without the lover's stone.

original: sūtakāntasamāyogād rasāyanam udīritam // /🔽lohakiṭṭaṃ tu kiṭṭaṃ syāl lohacūrṇam ayomalam /
analyzed: sūta kānta samāyogāt rasāyanam udīritam
translated: The elixir is said to come from the combination of mercury and the lover's stone.🔽The dross of iron is the dross, the iron powder is the iron dirt.

original: lohajaṃ kṛṣṇacūrṇaṃ ca kārṣṇyaṃ lohamalaṃ tathā // /🔽lohakiṭṭaṃ tu madhuraṃ kaṭūṣṇaṃ krimivātanut /🔽paktiśūlaṃ marucchūlaṃ mehagulmārtiśophanut // /
translated: The black powder from iron is also called blackness and iron dirt.🔽The iron dross is sweet, hot and pungent, and destroys worms and wind.
It cures indigestion, colic, flatulence, diabetes, abdominal tumors, and swelling.🔽The nine types of iron are: the head, the head iron, the iron, the stone essence, the stone-born,

original: aśmajaṃ kṛṣilohaṃ ca āraṃ kṛṣṇāyasaṃ nava // /
analyzed: aśmajam kṛṣiloham ca āram kṛṣṇāyasam nava
translated: the stone-born, the plow iron, the black iron, and the new.

original: tīkṣṇaṃ śastrāyasaṃ śastraṃ piṇḍaṃ piṇḍāyasaṃ śaṭham /
analyzed: tīkṣṇam śastrāyasam śastram piṇḍam piṇḍāyasam śaṭham
translated: The sharp iron is the weapon iron, the lump is the lump iron, and the deceitful is the deceitful iron.

original: āyasaṃ niśitaṃ tīvraṃ lohakhaḍgaṃ ca muṇḍajam /
analyzed: āyasam niśitam tīvram lohakhaḍgam ca muṇḍajam
translated: The iron sword is sharp, keen, and made of steel.

original: ayaścitrāyasaṃ proktaṃ cīnajaṃ vedabhūmitam // /🔽lohaṃ rūkṣoṣṇatiktaṃ syād vātapittakaphāpaham /
analyzed: ayaḥ citrāyasam proktam cīnajam veda bhū mitam
translated: The Chinese sword is said to be made of variegated iron, and is known as the sword of the land of the Vedas.🔽Iron is rough, hot, and bitter, and removes vata, pitta, and kapha.

original: pramehapāṇḍuraśūlaghnaṃ tīkṣṇaṃ muṇḍādhikaṃ smṛtam // /🔽svarṇaṃ samyagaśodhitaṃ śramakaraṃ svedāvahaṃ duḥsahaṃ raupyaṃ jāṭharajāḍyamāndyajananaṃ tāmraṃ vamibhrāntidam /
analyzed: svarṇam samyak aśodhitam śrama karam sveda āvaham duḥsaham raupyam jāṭhara jāḍya māndya jananam tāmram vami bhrānti dam
translated: It is said to be more effective than steel in curing diabetes, jaundice, and colic.🔽Gold, if not properly refined, causes fatigue, sweating, and is unbearable. Silver causes indigestion and dullness. Copper causes vomiting and confusion.

original: nāgaṃ ca trapu cāṅgadoṣadam ayo gulmādidoṣapradaṃ tīkṣṇaṃ śūlakaraṃ ca kāntam uditaṃ kārṣṇyāmayasphoṭadam // /🔽viśuddhihīnau yadi muṇḍatīkṣṇau kṣudhāpahau gauravagulmadāyakau /
analyzed: nāgam ca trapu ca aṅga doṣa dam ayaḥ gulma ādi doṣa pradam tīkṣṇam śūla karam ca kāntam uditam kārṣṇya āmaya sphoṭa dam  viśuddhi hīnau yadi muṇḍa tīkṣṇau kṣudhā apahau gaurava gulma dāyakau
translated: Lead and tin cause skin diseases. Iron causes gulma and other diseases. Steel causes colic. Magnetite is said to cause black discoloration and blisters.🔽If steel and iron are not properly refined, they remove hunger but cause heaviness and gulma.

analyzed: kāṃsya āyasam kledaka tāpa kārakam ca sammohana śoṣa dāyike
translated: Brass and iron cause moistening and burning, and lead and tin cause confusion and drying.

translated: Manahshila is also known as kunati, manojna, shila, manojava, and nagajihva.

original: nepālikā syān manasaś ca guptā kalyāṇikā rogaśilā daśāhvā // /
translated: Nepalisha is also known as manahgupta, kalyanika, rogashila, and dasahva.
Red arsenic is pungent, unctuous, scraping, and destroys poison.

original: bhūtāveśabhayonmādahāriṇī vaśyakāriṇī // /🔽sindūraṃ nāgareṇuḥ syād raktaṃ sīmantakaṃ tathā /
translated: It removes possession by spirits, fear, insanity, and causes subjugation.🔽Vermilion is also called nagarenu, red, and simantaka.

original: nāgajaṃ nāgagarbhaṃ ca śoṇaṃ vīrarajaḥ smṛtam // /

translated: That which comes from an elephant, is in the womb of an elephant, is red, is known as the pollen of a hero.

analyzed: saubhāgyam aruṇam ca eva maṅgalyam manu saṃmitam
translated: It is also called auspicious, red, and mangala, approved by Manu.

It is supreme in alleviating leprosy, bleeding, poison, itching, and erysipelas.

original: suraṅgo 'gnisahaḥ sūkṣmaḥ snigdhaḥ svaccho gurur mṛduḥ /

original: suvarṇakarajaḥ śuddhaḥ sindūro maṅgalapradaḥ // /🔽bhūnāgaḥ kṣitināgaś ca bhūjantū raktajantukaḥ /

kshitij, kshitejanta, bhumija, raktantaka.

translated: Other names of red arsenic are Marakam, Maniragam, Rasodbhavam,

translated: Suvarna-gaireekam, Svarna-dhatu, Suraktakam,
Sandhya-bharam, Babhru-dhatu, and Shila-dhatu are the six names of red ochre.

original: visphoṭārśo'gnidāhaghnaṃ varaṃ svarṇādikaṃ śubham // /🔽tuvarī mṛc ca saurāṣṭrī mṛtsnā saṅgā surāṣṭrajā /

analyzed: tuvarī tikta kaṭukā kaṣāyā amlā ca lekhanī

original: cakṣuṣyā grahaṇīchardipittasaṃtāpahāriṇī // /🔽haritālaṃ godantaṃ pītaṃ naṭamaṇḍanaṃ ca gauraṃ ca /
analyzed: cakṣuṣyā grahaṇī chardi pitta saṃtāpa hāriṇī  haritālam godantam pītam naṭamaṇḍanam ca gauram ca
translated: It is good for the eyes, removes indigestion, vomiting, bile, and fever.🔽Yellow orpiment, cow's tooth, yellow, dancer's ornament, and white.

translated: Colorful, reddish-yellow, and yellow are the types of orpiment, also known as talaka and tala.

analyzed: kanakarasam kāñcanakam biḍālakam ca eva citragandham ca
translated: Gold essence, kanchana, cat's eye, and colorful fragrance.

translated: Putrid smell, excessive smell, banyan, and saugandhika.

original: sugandho divyagandhaś ca gandhaś ca rasagandhakaḥ /

analyzed: gandhakaḥ kaṭuḥ uṣṇaḥ ca tīvra gandhaḥ ti vahni kṛt
translated: Sulphur is pungent, hot, has a strong smell, and greatly increases digestive fire.

original: śveto raktaś ca pītaś ca nīlaś ceti caturvidhaḥ /
analyzed: śvetaḥ raktaḥ ca pītaḥ ca nīlaḥ ca iti caturvidhaḥ
translated: Sulphur is of four types: white, red, yellow, and blue.

original: gandhako varṇato jñeyo bhinno bhinnaguṇāśrayaḥ // /🔽śvetaḥ kuṣṭhāpahārī syād rakto lohaprayogakṛt /
analyzed: gandhakaḥ varṇataḥ jñeyaḥ bhinnaḥ bhinna guṇa āśrayaḥ  śvetaḥ kuṣṭha apahārī syāt raktaḥ loha prayoga kṛt
translated: Sulphur should be known by its color, as it has different properties in each case.🔽The white one removes skin diseases, the red one is used in iron preparations,

analyzed: pītaḥ rasa prayoga arhaḥ nīlaḥ varṇa antara ucitaḥ
translated: the yellow one is suitable for mercury preparations, and the blue one is suitable for other colors.🔽Shilajatu is known as ashmudbhavam, shailam, girijam, asmajam,

original: aśmalākṣāśmajatukaṃ jatvaśmakam iti smṛtam // /🔽śilājatu bhavet tiktaṃ kaṭūṣṇaṃ ca rasāyanam /
analyzed: śilājatu bhavet tiktam kaṭu uṣṇam ca rasāyanam
translated: ashmalakshma, asmajatu, jatvasham, and asmakam.🔽Shilajatu is bitter, pungent, hot, and an elixir.

analyzed: sikthakam madhukam siktham madhujam madhusambhavam
translated: It destroys urinary diseases, insanity, urinary stones, swelling, skin diseases, and epilepsy.🔽Sikthakam, madhukam, siktham, madhujam, madhusambhavam,

translated: madanakam, madhukshistam, madanam, and makshikamalam are synonyms.🔽This is yellow-colored and glossy, and is also known as makshikajam.

original: madhūṣitaṃ ca samproktaṃ madhūtthaṃ conaviṃśati // /🔽sikthakaṃ kapilaṃ svādu kuṣṭhavātārtijin mṛdu /
analyzed: madhūṣitam ca samproktam madhūttham ca ūnaviṃśati
translated: And that produced from honey is said to be of twenty-one types.🔽The honey-bee is sweet, cures skin diseases and wind disorders, and is soft.

analyzed: kaṭu snigdham ca lepena sphuṭita aṅga viropaṇam
translated: It is pungent and unctuous, and when applied as a paste, it heals wounds.

analyzed: kāsīsam dhātukāsīsam kesaram haṃsalomaśam
translated: Red arsenic, mineral arsenic, saffron, and swan-down arsenic,

original: śodhanaṃ pāṃśukāsīsaṃ śubhraṃ saptāhvayaṃ matam // /🔽kāsīsaṃ tu kaṣāyaṃ syāt śiśiraṃ viṣakuṣṭhajit /
translated: are purifying. White arsenic is considered to be of seven types.🔽Red arsenic is astringent, cold, and cures poison and skin diseases.

analyzed: kharjū krimi haram ca eva cakṣuṣyam kānti vardhanam
translated: It is also anti-helminthic, good for the eyes, and increases luster.

analyzed: dvitīyam puṣpakāsīsam vatsakam ca malīmasam
translated: The second type is flower arsenic, also called vatsaka and malimsa.

original: hrasvaṃ netrauṣadhaṃ yojyaṃ viśadaṃ nīlamṛttikā // /🔽puṣpakāsīsaṃ tiktaṃ śītaṃ netrāmayāpaham /
translated: The short one should be used as an eye medicine, the clear one as blue clay.🔽Flower arsenic is bitter and cold, and removes eye diseases.

analyzed: lepena ati āma kuṣṭha ādi nānā tvac doṣa nāśanam
translated: When applied as a paste, it destroys various skin diseases such as excessive swelling and skin diseases.

analyzed: mākṣikam ca eva mākṣīkam pītakam dhātumākṣikam
translated: Honey and honey-bee are yellow, and mineral honey.
That produced in the Tapī region is tāpya, tāpya, āpīta, and yellow honey.

analyzed: āvartam madhudhātuḥ syāt kṣaudradhātuḥ tathā aparaḥ
translated: Honey-bee is also called āvarta, madhu-dhātu, and kṣaudra-dhātu.

analyzed: proktam mākṣikadhātuḥ ca veda bhūḥ hemamākṣikam
translated: And the mineral called Makshika, which is the source of gold and silver, is also known as Hema-Makshika.

analyzed: mākṣikam madhuram tiktam amlam kaṭu kapha apaham
translated: Makshika is sweet, bitter, sour, pungent and alleviates kapha.

analyzed: bhrama hṛllāsa mūrchā ārti śvāsa kāsa viṣa apaham
translated: It removes giddiness, nausea, fainting, shivering, cough, dyspnea and poison.

analyzed: mākṣikam dvividham proktam hema āhvam tāramākṣikam
translated: Makshika is said to be of two types - Hema (gold-colored) and Tara-Makshika (silver-colored).

analyzed: bhinna varṇa viśeṣa tvāt rasa vīrya ādikam pṛthak
translated: Due to the difference in color, the rasa (taste), veerya (potency), etc. are different.

analyzed: tāra vāda ādike tāramākṣikam ca praśasyate
translated: In Tara-vada (treatment of silver poisoning), Tara-Makshika is recommended.

analyzed: dehe hema ādikam śastam roga hṛt bala puṣṭi dam
translated: In the body, gold and other metals are beneficial, removing diseases and giving strength and nourishment.

original: añjanaṃ yāmunaṃ kṛṣṇaṃ nādeyaṃ mecakaṃ tathā /
translated: The collyrium is Yamuna, Krishna, Nadiya, Mechaka,

original: srotojaṃ dṛkpradaṃ nīlaṃ sauvīraṃ ca suvīrajam // /
analyzed: srotojam dṛkpradam nīlam sauvīram ca suvīrajam
translated: Srotojaya, eye-giving, blue, Sauvira, and Suviraja.

analyzed: tathā nīlāñjanam ca eva cakṣuṣyam vārisambhavam
translated: Similarly, the blue collyrium is also beneficial for the eyes and is produced from water.

analyzed: muktā saumyā mauktikam mauktikeyam tāram tārā bhautikam tārakā ca

analyzed: ambhaḥsāram śītalam nīrajam ca nakṣatram syāt indraratnam valakṣam

original: mauktikaṃ ca madhuraṃ suśītalaṃ dṛṣṭirogaśamanaṃ viṣāpaham /

destroys diseases of the head such as tuberculosis, and increases the strength and vigor of the weak.

translated: But a pearl that is placed on a scale and does not bear its weight, that is priceless and brings happiness.

translated: which is like the eye of a fish, rough, raised, and low, should not be worn by a wise person, as it brings harm.

original: mātaṃgoragamīnapotriśirasas tvaksāraśaṅkhāmbubhṛt śuktīnāmudarācca mauktikamaṇiḥ spaṣṭaṃ bhavatyaṣṭadhā /

translated: The pearl gem is clearly found in eight ways from the bellies of elephants, snakes, fish, porpoises, and oysters, from the bark of trees, and from shells and water.

translated: It is thrown into a vessel filled with salt, alkali, and water, and with cow's urine.

analyzed: pravālaḥ madhura umlaḥ ca kapha pitta ādi doṣa nud

Garuda's vomit, born from the womb of the jewel of Mercury,

translated: The Pushparaga is sour and cold, it conquers wind, is an excellent digestive stimulant,

translated: Six-sided, with many edges, equal to a hundred million oceans and lands,🔽And the diamond endowed with six tastes removes all diseases.🔽It pacifies all sins, brings happiness, strengthens the body, and is an elixir.

translated: The diamond with ash-colored parts, crow's foot, crossed by lines, round,🔽Without a base, dirty, with drops of fear, cracked,

translated: When worn, it is an appetizer, digestive, and destroyer of sins.🔽If it is pale like cow's urine, soft, smooth, glossy, and heavy,

original: siddhāḥ pāradam abhrakaṃ ca vividhān dhātūṃś ca lohāni ca prāhuḥ kiṃca maṇīnapīha sakalān saṃskārataḥ siddhidān /
analyzed: siddhāḥ pāradam abhrakam ca vividhān dhātūn ca lohāni ca prāhuḥ kiṃca maṇīn api iha sakalān saṃskārataḥ siddhi dān
translated: The Siddhas have said that mercury, mica, various metals and iron, and also all gems, when purified, bestow success.

original: yat saṃskāravihīnam eṣu hi bhaved yaccānyathā saṃskṛtaṃ tanmartyaṃ viṣavan nihanti tadiha jñeyā budhaiḥ saṃskriyāḥ // /
analyzed: yat saṃskāra vihīnam eṣu hi bhavet yat ca anyathā saṃskṛtam tat martyam viṣa vat nihanti tat iha jñeyāḥ budhaiḥ saṃskriyāḥ
translated: That which is devoid of purification among these, and that which is purified otherwise, should be known by the wise to be mortal and to destroy like poison.

original: yān saṃskṛtān śubhaguṇān atha cānyathā ced doṣāṃś ca yān api diśanti rasādayo 'mī /
analyzed: yān saṃskṛtān śubha guṇān atha ca anyathā ced doṣān ca yān api diśanti rasa ādayaḥ
translated: The good qualities that are obtained by purifying these, and the faults that are caused by other methods, are caused by mercury and other substances.

original: yāś ceha santi khalu saṃskṛtayas tadetan nātrābhyadhāyi bahuvistarabhītibhāgbhiḥ // /
analyzed: yāḥ ca iha santi khalu saṃskṛtayaḥ tat etat bahu vistara bhīti bhāgbhiḥ

analyzed: iti loha dhātu rasa ratna tad bhidā ādi abhidhā guṇa prakaṭana sphuṭa akṣaram

original: kurvanti ye nijaguṇena rasādhvagena nṝṇāṃ jarantyapi vapūṃṣi punarnavāni /
analyzed: kurvanti ye nija guṇena rasa adhva gena nṝṇām jaranti api vapūṃṣi punarnavāni
translated: Those who, by their own qualities, make the bodies of men, though old, youthful again,

translated: Their abode is this group of gold and others, which is known by the name of Rasayana Varga.

original: nityaṃ yasya guṇāḥ kilāntaralasatkalyāṇabhūyas tathā cittākarṣaṇacañcavas tribhuvanaṃ bhūmnā parikurvate /
analyzed: nityam yasya guṇāḥ kila antara lasat kalyāṇa bhūyaḥ tathā citta ākarṣaṇa cañcavaḥ tribhuvanam bhūmnā parikurvate
translated: Whose qualities, it is said, always attract the mind of the three worlds with their abundant goodness,

original: tenātraiṣa kṛte nṛsiṃhakṛtinā nāmādicūḍāmaṇau saṃsthāmeti mitas trayodaśatayā vargaḥ suvarṇādikaḥ // /
